t: Woe*pn to the land of buzzing insect wings beyond*ln the rivers of Cush,

which*ln sends envoys by sea, in*ln reed vessels over the water. Go,*ln swift messengers, to*ln a nation tall and smooth-skinned, to*ln a people feared far and near, a*ln powerful nation with a strange language, whose*ln land is divided by rivers.
All*ln you inhabitants of the world and*ln you who live on the earth, when*ln a banner is raised on the mountains, look! When*ln a ram’s horn sounds, listen!
For*p the Lord*s said to me: I*pn will quietly look out from my place, like*ln shimmering heat in sunshine, like*ln a rain cloud in harvest heat.
For*ln before the harvest, when the blossoming is over and*ln the blossom becomes a ripening grape, he*ln will cut off the shoots with a pruning knife, and*ln tear away and remove the branches.

They*ln will all be left for the birds of prey on the hills and*ln for the wild animals of the land. The*ln birds of prey will spend the summer feeding on them, and*ln all the wild animals the winter.

At*p that time a gift will be brought to the Lord*s of Armies from a people tall and smooth-skinned, a people feared far and near, a powerful nation with a strange language, whose land is divided by rivers — to Mount Zion, the place of the name of the Lord*s of Armies.
